data.text: Bicycle Touring with the Celiac Disease

Are there any fellow celiacs out there that tour? I was diagnosed after my last big trip ended and I'm eager to get back out there, but all my staples are on the forbidden list now. I can't do oats either, which is exceedingly unfortunate for breakfasts. Do you have any suggestions for breakfasts and lunches that are packable? Dinners are fine (rice), but for lunches I used to always do flour tortillas. These little shredders will be with me, so I won't have a ton of space for fancy stuff. I'll be carrying too many of their rocks and stuffed animals.

I believe you can buy gluten free oats -oats don't contain gluten but are often contaminated during processing. Might be hard to find away from major centres. Corn tortillas might be a good substitute for the flour ones. Quinoa might also be a good breakfast food. I think you can buy quinoa flakes which don't require a lot of cooking time. Adorable kids!

data.text: My wife has celiac. Instant polenta is another breakfast option, as are all the grain free granolas aimed at the paleo crowd. The paleo granolas are pricey but nutrient dense, so great for packing. We have often found other sorts of GF wraps, but they tend to be more fragile. Best large crackers are Yehuda GF matzos and Trader Joe‚Äôs GF Norwegian whole grain crackers. My wife usually carries a couple of pieces of light Tupperware-like stuff specially to keep the GF crackers whole in her panniers.

data.text: are sweet potatoes OK?
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: Sweet potatoes should be OK. Corn should be ok and there are lots of recipes for corn breads and some are almost cake and it is great for pancakes too. Corn flour/meal is avaiable in many countries. It is also naturally sweet so the kids should like it too. Corn breads are made with batter and can easily be cooked in a skillet like a pancake and I have even seen people making steam ovens using camping pots and a cup on Youtube. A lot of recipes call for butter, but you can easily substitute cooking oil for the butter, 1ml for every gram. It works just as well.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Hardboiled eggs.
data.author: Todd Ostler

data.text: I could usually find gf crackers even in the sticks, so I usually had crackers + cheese or pb for lunch, with some fruit and jerky. As others have said, grits are good for breakfast and easy to find, as well as GF granola. I carried granola + nuts with me most days, and grabbed yogurt from gas stations to make it breakfast. Cream of rice is good too, though hard to find; you'd have to bring it with you.
data.author: Sara Draper

data.text: Cereal with powdered milk, corn nuts or other dried corn, cheese, tuna, dried meat, nuts, instant mashed potatoes, rice crackers (or other GF cracker), dried fruit, hummus, etc. if you don't want to cook.
